I think interactive evolutionary computation has a lot of 
potential.  Have you seen "Morph Lab?"  I think it's basically what 
Dawkins did:

http://alife.fusebox.com/morph_lab.html

You can play with it yourself there.

Of course these kinds of apps are limited by their very greedy 
single-user evaluation wherein a user rewards only one organism in 
the entire population for each generation.

It's interesting to speculate how it would be possible to have a 
more sophisticated speciated/NEAT-style evolutionary system yet 
still with interactive input.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
> On Thu, 10 Jun 2004 16:02:45 -0000, Philip Tucker <ptucker@g...> 
wrote:
> > You'd pretty much have to have interaction with humans for the
> > fitness function, right?  
> 
> Yes, I think it would be interesting to have a website where people
> could visit, which would load up two ANN-controlled faces.  The 
user
> could be asked to observe each face for a set amount of time 
(e.g., 30
> seconds), and choose the one that looked "more natural".  Success
> would be contingent upon lots of traffic, but it would be an
> interesting fitness function.
> 
> I'm reminded of Richard Dawkins in "The Blind Watchmaker", I 
think. 
> He uses himself as the fitness function for evolving digital 
images of
> creatures, like wasps.  The computer just initially created random
> bitmap pictures, like 100x100.  He would pick the ones that "looked
> more like a wasp", and they would then survive and mutate.  
Eventually
> he got bitmaps that looked like a whole lot like wasps.  (I could 
be
> butchering the explanation...it's been a long time since I've read
> that bit...)
> 
> But the concept of using human judgment as a fitness function is 
still
> interesting and valid, I would think.
> 
> Derek
